multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 depicts an optimal 2-coloring of the Hajós graph. What is the minimum defect achievable in any 2-coloring of this graph?
Formula (1) defines the defect of a vertex *v* in a k-coloring. What does the expression min(*f<sub>j</sub>(v)*, *f<sub>j</sub>(w)*) represent in this formula?
choices: The smaller of the usages of color *j* on vertices *v* and *w*.
The total usage of color *j* on vertex *v*.
The difference in usage of color *j* between vertices *v* and *w*.
The total defect of the graph.

multiple_choice_question.text: Corollary 1 provides the total defect of a complete graph *K<sub>n</sub>* with *k* colors (TD(*K<sub>n</sub>*,*k*)). What does this corollary imply about the optimal coloring strategy for minimizing total defect in a complete graph?
choices: Using a single color for all vertices minimizes total defect.
Distributing colors as unevenly as possible among vertices minimizes total defect.
The total defect is independent of the coloring strategy.
Distributing colors as evenly as possible among vertices minimizes total defect.

multiple_choice_question.text: Lemma 3 states that if the minimum defect D(G, *k*) of a graph G with *k* colors is greater than 0, then D(G, *k*)  ≥ 1. What is the significance of this lemma?
choices: It implies that a graph can always be colored with zero defect.
It indicates that achieving a fractional defect less than 1 is impossible unless a perfect coloring exists.
It highlights that increasing the number of colors always reduces the minimum defect.
It proves that the minimum defect is always an integer value.
